thesis.description: The intriguing aspect of the poetry of E. J. Pratt is the oomplexity underlying the apparent simplicity. A study of The Witches' Brat;", Ihe Great Feud, Ibe Cachalot, The Titanic, Brbeuf and His Brethren as well as several shorter poems points to a recurring symbol, the Titan. The way 1n which Pratt develops a mythology around this symbol is examined in this paper. Inherent in the Iitan symbol is poweriI Four aspects of power which go to make up Pratt's cosmology are investigated first, mechanistio power which is blind, inhuman and awesome. Opposing mechanism is creative power allied to the fecundity of Nature. The third and fourth aspects lie in the human sphere and Can be polarized as the destructive force of hate and the creative force of love. Symbols portraying these four dimensions connect the worlds of impulse and reason. Interaction between these two worlds results 1n apocalyptic dissolution allied to the cyclio principle of life feeding on life [...]
